messageBody:
David Boyer wrote:
> I happen to have a similar situation, there's no easy
> to reset the
> database to a specific known good configuration and
> ensure that it's in
> that state I need when I run my tests. When I shared
> this situation and
> my different ideas of how to deal with it, the
> suggestions I got all
> centered on one method of handling it: abstract the
> unmanageable behind

In our case it is both unmanageable and unimaginable :-)

> interfaces and run my tests using a MockObject
> implementation of those
> interfaces.
>
> In your case is the mainframe specific code abstracted
> out of the
> testable functionality? If so you can test using a
> Mock implementation
> of the mainframe.
It seems like for unit testing, mock objects might
get you somewhere. For higher level testing, though, like
functional testing, the effort to code mock objects
would approach the effort to re-code the mainframe system (now THERE'S an idea :-) )

> The other side someone else already
> suggested which
> is to ensure that the generated batch code matches
> known good examples.
> Simply set up the fake data which would generate one of
> your known good
> examples, and run the code in a unit test and check the
> output in the
> testFunction().
Yep, this has some promise, also,
thanks, all.

Erik O.
